image.altText: A composite image of two women and one young boy.

props.synopsis: Day one of a temporary ceasefire in the Israel-Gaza war ends with Hamas releasing about double the number of hostages previously announced by authorities and 39 Palestinian prisoners being freed from Israeli jails.

title.children: Surprise as extra hostages released on tense first day of Israel-Gaza ceasefire

image.altText: A photo of Anthony Albanese's cabinet posing for a photo around a large oval table

props.synopsis: Between Australia's economic situation and the crisis in the Middle East, there has been a growing sense that the government is not in control of events — and it's throwing out lots of chaff, writes Laura Tingle.

title.children: Between crises at home and abroad, the government is striving to show it's hard at work. You just have to sort through the chaff

image.altText: A man in winter coat and scarf in front of a mountain and building.

props.synopsis: The mother of a victim who was groomed by a former Yorke Peninsula teacher has criticised her son's abuser, saying he used the region as a "hunting ground" to pick out the most vulnerable children that would not speak up.

title.children: Victim's family hit back at child sex abuser's 'no substance' apology

image.altText: A man squats over fire damaged posessions

props.synopsis: Residents whose homes have been destroyed and lives turned upside down by a massive fire that's torn through Perth's north-east return to their properties to pick up the pieces.

title.children: Yohann Catherine and his family didn't take the Perth fire seriously. Now they have 'nothing left'

image.altText: Figuring out how to save money on energy bill

props.synopsis: The retail price of electricity has an in-built 12-month lag by design. This means the energy bill relief could be in place now, but the system does not allow it, writes David Taylor.

title.children: Your electricity bills could be a lot cheaper right now, if only the system would allow it

image.altText: a person standing outdoors on a wheat farme next to machinery with storm clouds brewing and their arms up high

props.synopsis: As Western Australia sweats through the hottest November on record, eastern states are rejoicing through an extended run of stormy days.

title.children: Eastern storm outbreak saves spring while WA bakes in record-hot November

image.altText: A gun being fired off a boat on the ocean with blue sky above

props.synopsis: Just days after a Chinese warship caused minor injuries to Australian defence personnel, the US Navy is warning Beijing to respect international law.

title.children: United States warns China to be 'safe and professional' following sonar attack on Australian naval divers

image.altText: A person films themselves cooking through an iphone.

props.synopsis: More and more social media seems like an all-in adult version of children's playground games, where nobody's ever out, and where the game — and the joke — just goes round and round, writes Virginia Trioli.

title.children: I don't know who needs to hear this, but ... the playground imitation games of social media are getting old

image.altText: A crowd of protesters, with one holding a sign reading 'enough is enough'.

props.synopsis: Advocates call for stronger action to address gender-based violence in South Australia following the deaths of four women in unrelated cases over the past week.

title.children: Protestors rally on steps of parliament to call for royal commission after four women killed in SA

image.altText: a zoomed out picture of a ship in the middle of the ocean

props.synopsis: Taiwan's defence ministry said an Australian ship, understood to be the HMAS Toowoomba, has sailed through the strategic waterway, after its personnel were injured by a Chinese sonar pulse.

title.children: China reacts after Australian warship HMAS Toowoomba transits Taiwan Strait

image.altText: Bruce Lehrmann arrives with coffee at the Federal Court.

props.synopsis: Bruce Lehrmann is suing Network Ten and Lisa Wilkinson over coverage in which Brittany Higgins alleged she was raped in Parliament House in 2019.

title.children: 'I was wrong': Bruce Lehrmann concedes he bought drinks for Brittany Higgins despite earlier saying he couldn't recall

image.altText: A police officer speaks to the media.

props.synopsis: Victoria Police Detective Senior Sergeant Paul Lineham has been temporarily appointed as a Special Constable and will have control of the direction and outcome of the investigation.

title.children: Independent investigator appointed to oversee Charlie Stevens investigation

image.altText: A close-up shot of a man with short hair and a stubble, not looking happy.

props.synopsis: South African Paralympian Oscar Pistorius is granted parole after serving 10 years for the 2013 murder of his girlfriend, Reeva Steenkamp.

title.children: Oscar Pistorius granted parole after serving 10 years for the murder of Reeva Steenkamp

image.altText: Charred ground on the porch of a home destroyed in a bushfire, with windows scorched and burnt out.

props.synopsis: The massive bushfire that destroyed 18 homes in Perth's north is no longer being treated as an emergency level fire as the wind and heat eases across the city.

title.children: Emergency threat passes for residents in line of fire as Perth weather conditions ease

image.altText: An artists impression of a large energy battery storage area.

props.synopsis: A multi-national energy company has announced plans for a renewable energy battery park near Mount Gambier which it says will reduce electricity price volatility.

title.children: SA's largest battery park worth 'several hundred million dollars' slated for Limestone Coast

image.altText: A bright fire burning during a dark night behind a lamp post and traffic lights

props.synopsis: Police have blamed far-right agitators for starting the violence after a small group of anti-immigrant protesters arrived at the scene of a stabbing attack where five people were injured.

title.children: Irish police arrest 34 after Dublin stores looted, vehicles torched following stabbing

image.altText: A large crowd of protestors outside Flinders Street Station. One student waves a Palestinian flag in the air.

props.synopsis: Pro-Palestinian rallies have been going on for weeks across the country. The protests are dominated by young people.

title.children: Hundreds of high school students break the rules in walkout for pro-Palestine protest

image.altText: A black F1 car, ahead of an orange car, down the straight during a night race

props.synopsis: Mercedes-powered cars have won 114 of the 203 grands prix since the start of 2014, including eight constructors' championships for the factory-Mercedes team.

title.children: Newest engine deal of F1's new era signed as McLaren and Mercedes continue historic partnership

image.altText: panoramic image of mansion on mountain with sea scape in background

props.synopsis: The federal police attempt to enforce a US restraining order in Australia to take control of a New South Wales South Coast mansion being sold by Daniel Duggan's wife to fund his legal bills.

title.children: 'Lapdog diplomacy' at work in AFP's property freeze over former US pilot on conspiracy charge, lawyer says

image.altText: Woman's hand holds a credit card in front of a computer

props.synopsis: Scammers are creating fake websites that replicate popular brands during Black Friday sales, but experts say paying attention to red flags can help you avoid getting caught out.

title.children: Scam shopping sites have raked in $500,000 this year. Here's how to spot them on Black Friday

image.altText: A pontoon off a reef in Cairns.

props.synopsis: The South Australian man, who was found unresponsive while snorkelling, was pulled out of the water, but attempts to revive him were unsuccessful.

title.children: Investigations launched into death of man on Great Barrier Reef snorkelling tour

image.altText: A plume of smoke rises above a city dotted with buildings.

props.synopsis: As part of a temporary ceasefire deal, Hamas has begun releasing Israeli hostages in exchange for Palestinian prisoners. But with thousands more remaining in detention inside Israel and hundreds of captives in Gaza, there is still a long way to go.

title.children: These are some of the Palestinian prisoners who could be released as part of the Israel-Gaza hostage deal

image.altText: A view at Howard Springs as staff prepare for evacuation.

props.synopsis: Coroner Elisabeth Armitage will investigate the deaths of three people who had been detained in Australia's "gold standard" quarantine facility during the COVID-19 pandemic. She will consider the quality of care at the centre as well as the legalities around mandatory quarantine.

title.children: Coroner to probe deaths of three people held at Howard Springs COVID facility

image.altText: Father and daughter pose next to broken cyclone wire.

props.synopsis: When three-year-old Sophia was stabbed in the eye by a stray piece of fence wiring while walking along a footpath, her father Kain asked the local council and rail company if they could fix the fence. But both authorities said the fence belonged to the other.

title.children: After his daughter was injured by a 'dangerous' fence, Kain couldn't get the authorities to say who owns it

image.altText: An aerial photograph showing Sydney city with the Rozelle highway development in the centre.

props.synopsis: After years of development, Sydneysiders will have access to 24 kilometres of underground tunnels when the Rozelle interchange opens this weekend.

title.children: Sydney's new complex underground road interchange set for Sunday opening

image.altText: A crowd of people face a brightly lit stage with the words 'Spilt Milk' atop it.

props.synopsis: Pill testing will be available on-site at an Australian music festival for the first time since 2019, with Pill Testing Australia confirming the service will be available at the Spilt Milk festival in Canberra on Saturday.

title.children: Pill testing will be available on-site at an Australian music festival for the first time in four years

image.altText: Ambulances in emergency driveway at Ipswich hospital, west of Brisbane

props.synopsis: The Queensland government has pledged $20 million towards hiring more triage nurses, creating medical commanders, and improving access to medical imaging at hospitals across the state.

title.children: More triage nurses, expanded medical imaging access to help combat hospital wait times and ambulance ramping

image.altText: Peter Dutton in the prime minister's courtyard

props.synopsis: Federal Opposition Leader Peter Dutton raised the prospect of a "catastrophic outcome" as the result of Palestinians receiving visitor visas to come to Australia amid the Israel-Gaza war.

title.children: Peter Dutton links visas for Palestinians with prospect of a 'catastrophic outcome' for Australia

image.altText: A man swimming in a flood-hit dining room.

props.synopsis: Receiving 50 millimetres of welcome rain in 30 minutes the Packsaddle Roadhouse, 170km north of Broken Hill, had to quickly batten down the hatches, in stark contrast with residents bracing themselves for the inevitable summer months.

title.children: Outback roadhouse turns into an indoor swimming pool after much-needed rains

image.altText: A man wearing a wide-brim hat walks into a police station to report for bail.

props.synopsis: Jurors are set to begin deliberations in the trial of 57-year-old Shane Plunkett, who claims he shot 38-year-old Luke Freeman in self defence in Norseman last year.

title.children: Shooter labelled 'judge, jury and executioner' before jurors retire to decide his fate

image.altText: Julia Garner and Jessica Henwick squint in the outback, wearing huge backpacks, in the film The Royal Hotel.

props.synopsis: The Royal Hotel probes the darker side of masculinity as magnified by a remote outback setting and alcohol consumption on a liver-defying scale — and evokes the spectre of horror without ever actually letting it loose.

title.children: 'Gonna have to be OK with male attention': Australian drinking culture through the eyes of two outsiders

image.altText: Scorched earth and trees in a park after a bushfire.

props.synopsis: Fire crews are into their third day battling a large bushfire in Perth's north-east, with better conditions overnight offering some respite for residents and authorities — but a forecast wind change is causing concerns.

title.children: 'Critical' day for Perth bushfire emergency with likely wind change as temperatures ease

image.altText: A woman lighting a cigarette

props.synopsis: Police across Australia have arrested 25 people and seized $200,000 in cash as part of an operation targeting the Finks and Comanchero outlaw motorcycle gangs.

title.children: Police seize 134,000 illegal cigarettes alongside steroids, vapes and firearms

image.altText: Children on a roof drop a bucket of water on children standing on a suburban street in the middle of the day

props.synopsis: Last week, the planet appeared to briefly breach a climate threshold set by world governments for the first time. Experts say it is just another sign of how much the planet is warming.

title.children: Earth briefly surpassed a crucial temperature milestone last week. Experts say there's more to be worried about

image.altText: A woman in a red dress and a man kissing under a flowery arbor.

props.synopsis: A wedding celebrant has hatched a one-of-a-kind fundraiser — marrying four couples in one afternoon, with a hair, make-up and photography package for the budget price of less than $1,000.

title.children: Why four couples got married at the same venue on the same afternoon
